This class does a poor job integrating epidemiology with immunology.
Good intro to Immuno, expectations are clear and the information on the slides is useful.

I love the subject of immunology and took an undergraduate course in it, so I came in with high expectations (which were met). The material was rigorous, and went in depth into topics that were briefly mentioned in the undergraduate course. The lecture notes were very detailed and greatly aided my understanding of the material.

One thing I wish is for more of an epidemiological application. We mostly covered the biology for the majority of the semester. The only epidemiology covered was after the final exam, during group presentations, and for the final paper. Going forward, some curriculum adjustment would be good.
Immunology is difficult if you do not have any background in it but Professor Krause worked hard to make it as simple as possible

This was a very good comprehensive presentation of basic immunology. My one query however, is where was the epidemiology component. I can think of only a single lecture that presented a clear epidemiological implication of immunology. Nevertheless, I think it was beneficial that this course was heavy in the biological sciences. I do with that slightly more detail was given into molecular mechanisms, but understand that the course is based on a book that does not dig into that type of detail. A complaint that I have is that lectures did little to go beyond the content of the book. Whenever this is the case, it is tempting to simply read the book to obtain the information. However, Dr. Krause did embellish his lectures verbally with experiential information that surpassed the bound of the book.

I knew next to nothing about immunology prior to this course and I can happily say that this is not the case anymore.  I fully enjoyed my time in this class as it was very interesting and informative.
I enjoyed this course greatly, I have learned so much and thought it was well organized in its content and material

Strengths: learned many basic concepts of how the immune system works, textbook is a good resource for the class

Weaknesses: absolutely no epidemiology was incorporated into the course, course was very fast

Suggestions: Either incorporate how we can use immunology for epidemiology, or take out the "for Epidemiologists" part of the course name and not make it a requirement for EMD students
Great mix of exams, presentations, and essays.
This course gives a very good overview of immunology.

I thought it was interesting but I wish it weren't a required class for EMD. It was heavily based on the immunology aspect, which I thought would be appealing to those who are interested in medical school but not so for those who aren't.
I love this course. This course gave me a refresh of memory over college immunology, as well as some new insights on how immunology may help public health development.

Tests are pretty fair, based on memorization from the slides. Group projects were fu.

Lectures could be improved so that it is not a read-through of the words on the slides. I did not like having to rush through the material and take the final exam so early, but I appreciated not having a sit-down final during final exam week.
It is a very good course which gives an introduction of immunology.

Overall I thought this was a fantastic course.  It helps provide an in-depth understanding of the body's immune system which perfectly compliments the Principles of Infectious Diseases course taken in the same semester.  This way students understand not just what symptoms/side effects infectious diseases cause but also how the body's immune response causes these symptoms to manifest.
Instructor does poor job engaging with students during lecture.

He went through lecture notes fast and did not add much of his own insight. However, that was not required, given how detailed the lecture notes are. Additionally, he responded very effectively to student questions during class.
Professor Krause did a great job breaking down all the information in a way that made it understandable for everyone, even those who have never taken an immunology course before

Dr. Krause is an extremely kind, contentious and humble person. These qualities are reflected in his teaching style. He is very receptive to students' questions and goes out of his way to dig up additional information and answers to questions that at first he does not have a clear response. Though he can lecture at quite a fast pace, and tends to read off of the slides, he provides intermitted additional insight about each topic that is highly relevant to medicine and public health.
Professor Krause was an excellent instructor.  Although the material was dense, he was always able to clear up any points of confusion and explain difficult concepts articulately.
Professor was not very engaging in class, helpful during office hours
The instructor explains the materials quite clearly. however, if we could have more time in the class to digest the materials, it would be much better.
Peter Krause was an excellent teacher, my only comment is he needs to slow down because he goes extremely fast through the material reading off the slides and its hard to absorb at such a fast rate
Very kind and incredibly passionate about the subject, reads through lectures very quickly.
Dr. Krause is a very kind person. I truly enjoyed his lectures.
Dr. Krause if a wonderful instructor who conveyed the course material very well. He also fostered a classroom environment that encouraged students to ask questions/ make comments.
I love his way of teaching and the material he presented. He is a great professor and willing to answer any question related or not related to the current topic.
Dr. Krause is such a nice professor, but I think his slides could be improved to be more concise such that what he talks about in class ADDS to the content on the powerpoint slides.
The prof is an expert in the content, but teaching style is not the most engaging and communication can be improved. Messages to class and even wording on course material was often very ambiguous.
Great teacher!
Professor Krause is extremely knowledgeable, receptive to feedback, and very proactive about helping students understand the material and make sure that they are thriving in the course.

If you are interested in immunology, this is a must-take. It covers a ton of material and will challenge you, but it is completely worth it. You will leave the class knowing a lot, and depending on your concentration, you will see how much your understanding of immunology will enhance whatever you learn.
Provides a solid basic understanding of immunology. The exams are difficult but fair. Presentations didn't require too much work and helped with understanding the topic on a more detailed level

I would recommend this course to another student with a non-science background who had not previously taken immunology. For those with science backgrounds (especially chemistry and molecular biology), this course may lack the detail that they may desire.
Highly recommend

I would not recommend this to a student who is hoping to learn more about immunoepidemiology. Unfortunately, this class is a requirement for EMD but should not be because there is no epidemiology aspect of the course.
A very well-organized course that gives a very good overview of immunology.
If you are interested in immunology, then I would recommend it. Otherwise, probably not.
This is a great course if you want to learn systematically about immunology, it is also very biologically focused therefore you need some previous knowledge of basic biology.
This is your classic introduction to immunology course. Memorize away, friend.

It is an elementary course of immunology. If you have little knowledge of immunology, this course is a perfect course for you. If you have learnt immunology in undergraduate, this course can be viewed as a great review.
It's a definite must for all EMD students and I highly recommend it to students in other tracks who are considering applying to medical school, nursing school, or PA school after their MPH at Yale.
